div.p: 1. VI.30 Wednesday.

Walk to the Capitol. Call at Gadsby’s to see Mr Silsbee, but he was gone to the Senate— Met C J Ingersoll and Lewis Williams. Went into the Senate Chamber and spoke with Mr Silsbee, about the Letter of I. L. and T. Hedge. Plymouth— Benton introduced to me his Colleague Buckner—and Felix Grundy of Tennessee— I met S. B. Barrell there— In the House Edward Everett’s Resolution to call for a copy of the 5th. Article of the Treaty September 1830 with the Chickasaws was taken up. Huntington made a speech to support it, and Polk a speech against it— A party movement from which I doubt if much good will come— The hour expired, and the apportionment Bill was called up— Hubbard replied at some length to the arguments against his motion— Sutherland and M’Carty of Indiana spoke against him— I revised a Note in pencil from the Speaker, urging me to sum up in reply— It was four O’Clock and great impatience in the House for the Question— I made a very short and incoherent Speech saying not half what I intended, and omitting several more forcible positions which occurred to me after it was all over— I recurred to the Constitution and to a calculation shewing that the Committee which fixed the ratio at 48000 had taken special care of their own States— It brought up Barstow of New-York—to vindicate himself and Polk to refute my positions— The question was taken by yeas and nays, and carried 98 to 96. to strike out 48000 and insert 44000. Polk then told me that he would give up the question— Holland of Maine who was on the Committee came to me with a calculation to shew that Maine was better off with 44000 than with 48000. Bates of Maine had already announced that he should vote for 44000. Evans had been all along with us, and spoke this day for 44000— Wickliffe thanked me for my calculations and said he had intended to present the same himself. Cambreleng congratulated me upon our success. I had despaired of the vote and was overjoyed at the Event— The whole Bill was to be modified in conformity to the change in the ratio, and the house adjourned at half past four.— I rode home rejoicing though much dissatisfied with my own performance— I wrote in the Evening to Governor Lincoln— J. Connell spent a couple of hours here— The Danish Claim Commission have adjourned till May.
2. V:15. Thursday.

Rode to the Capitol. Committee on Manufactures. Condict. Horn. Dayan there.— J. S. Barbour had been there, but was gone— Findlay and Worthington absent— One or two Memorials referred to the Committee were read.— Mr James Lynch of New-York sent a Message by Mr Dayan that he would wish to confer with the Committee before they should report upon the Frauds on the Revenue— Adjourned to meet on Saturday Morning. In the House Mr Everett’s call for an Article of the Chickasaw Treaty was taken up and Mr Polk, and Clay, of Alabama replied to Everett and Huntington. The hour expired, and the Apportionment Bill was taken up— Mr M’Kennon moved a Reconsideration of the Vote of Yesterday— A third part of the House were in the Senate Chamber, in reply to Mr Hayne and others upon his Resolution, for an immediate repeal of duties— There was a call of the House, and upwards of twenty members were reported absent. After they had been two or three times called over, the doors were closed, and several excuses made in behalf of
the sick— The Speaker then talked of sending the Sergeant at Arms to take the absent into custody when upon the motion of Mr Irvin of Ohio, the proceedings were suspended, and the doors were opened— The vote of reconsideration was taken, and prevailed—by 100 to 94— Two or three were absent who voted with us yesterday— Two or three voted against us now, who were absent yesterday, and there were two or three deserters— The Reconsideration placed the Bill just where it was before the vote was taken yesterday.— That is it restored the number 48000—with the motion of Mr Hubbard to strike it out and insert 44000— Allan of Kentucky moved to recommit the Bill with Instructions to reduce the ratio, so that the number of the House would not exceed 200 members— He asked the yeas and nays and the motion was rejected by a vote of 164 to 36— The house then adjourned, between 2 and 3. O’Clock.— Mr Burges told me that the reconsideration of this day was the effect of interference by some of the Senators— I went into the Senate chamber but they had just adjourned. Mr Clay having left his Speech unfinished— There was a crowded audience and among them many Ladies— Walking homewards I fell in with Mr Waggaman the new Senator from Louisiana, and walked with him till overtaken by the Carriage, in which were my wife and John’s two children— I came home with them— In the Evening Messrs. de Beaumont and de Tocqueville called to take leave— They are to depart to-morrow and to sail from New-York for France on the 10th.— John’s wife is quite unwell.
3. V. Friday.

Finished the version of the 73d. and began that of the 74th. Psalm— I called at the Senate chamber about half an hour before their meeting, and gave Mr Silsbee the Letter from the Hedges of Plymouth, and he promised to use his exertions to get their case provided for, in the Bill before the Senate— There was a great crowd assembled to hear the Speech of Mr Clay; which was continued but not finished— Just before the time of meeting I went to the House where the day was consumed chiefly upon private Claims. Mr Evans of Maine made a reply to the yesterday’s speech of C. C. Clay, upon Edward Everett’s Resolution calling for the 5th. Article of the Chickasaw Treaty of 1830— Then the hour expired— Mr Philemon Thomas of Louisiana, some days since had moved for a joint Committee to consider and Report upon the expediency of a centennial celebration of General George Washington’s Birth day— I asked Thomas to strike out the word General to which he consented. Adair proposed to insert the words Major-General, but withdrew his motion. Other formal amendments were made and the Resolution was adopted— The Committee on the part of the House is to consist of one member from each State— Mr Whittlesey of Ohio, Chairman of the Committee of Claims reported a joint Resolution to authorise the payments upon sundry contracts of the Commissioners of the Navy-Board, suspended by an opinion of the Attorney-General. Mr Whittlesey in his Report had made one mistake with regard to the contract of Newcomb, Richards, and Bryant, which he stated to be still in progress; but which I told him had been completed— He promised if he should find it so, to amend the report before it would be printed. There was no opposition to the Resolution which was read three times and passed— Three private Bills were considered in Committee of the whole, Wickliffe in the Chair— Two of them went through the Committee of the whole one with an Amendment— The third was the Bill for the relief of Mrs Susan Decatur—which was postponed till next Friday. Sutherland came to me, and said he wished to introduce some provision for the M’Knights, Decatur’s collateral Relations—and told me that Dr. Harvey Klapp, Ann M’Knight’s husband was dead, which I had seen in the newspapers— Carson came to me, and said he hoped I should assist
him in carrying through the Bill for Mrs Decatur— I said I would assist him at least with my vote— Mr Wayne of Georgia laid on my Table a pamphlet being a Report of a Committee of the Georgia Legislature, upon the imprisonment of the Missionaries to the Indians— The House adjourned before 3. I went in to the Library, and took out the first Volume of Smith’s Wealth of Nations— Rode home— After dinner Coll Towson and Mr Skinner informed me that the Board of Directors of Columbia College had chosen me to be one of their members— I expressed my thanks for the offer but declined accepting it from a consciousness of being unable to discharge its duties. They asked me not to decline positively but to take it into consideration which I promised I would— Coll. Howard, the member of the House from Baltimore, had introduced to me this Morning at the door of the House, a Mr Gibson of that place an importing merchant who wished to have some conversation with me— I appointed 7. O’Clock this Evening to see him, and he came. Mr Du Ponceau and Mr D’Homergue were here, at the same time— Mr Gibson complained of the frauds practiced upon the Revenue in the importation of Woollens—and said he had a partner in England, who had informed him frequently of the devices resorted to there by exporters for that purpose— The complaints are much the same as were those of Mr Schenk from New-York— Mr Gibson is to return to-morrow to Baltimore, and at my request promised to write to me, and to send me extracts from his partners Letters— Mr. Du Ponceau had sent as a present to Mrs Adams a piece of silk of American production manufactured in England—for a gown— At the motion of Genl. Root, Chairman of the Committee of Agriculture, next Tuesday week had this day been appointed as a special order to consider the Bill for Silk-reeling School reported by him— Mr Duponceau remains here till the decision upon that Bill.
4 V:15. Saturday.

Mr W. B. Hodgson called upon me this Morning— He has just returned from Constantinople, with a ratified Treaty and gave me some account of transactions at that place— The Capudan Pasha who met Commodore Rodgers in the army is now Seraskier, or commander in Chief of the Army. Mr Hodgson shewed me the Prospectus of a Turkish Newspaper which was about to be published in that Capital, and also his own Passport with the Sultans Sign Manual I went up to the Capitol to attend a Meeting of the Committee on Manufactures but had mistaken the day to which they had adjourned— It was to Monday, and Dr Condict asked me to meet them at ten O’Clock—to which I agreed— In the House Cave Johnson of Tennessee, Drayton of South-Carolina, and Clayton the new Member from Georgia occupied the hour and more upon Everett’s Resolution and the Chickasaw Treaty— Johnson opposed the call; but spoke in the severest terms of the Sabine Reservation bargains of Lewis the second Auditor and declared that they were utterly disapproved by the President himself— Clayton made a strange and by no means a wise Speech, dashing at the right hand and the left—opposing the call—abusing the mover and supporters of it, and finishing by offering an Amendment, with which he said he would vote for the original Resolution— It was a Second Resolution declaring that the House called for the 5th. Article of the Chickasaw Treaty because
they considered Indian Treaties to be no Treaties at all. After the expiration of the hour, the private Bills were taken up. There is a Rule of the House that not more than three Bills shall be committed to a Committee of the whole at once; but it is never observed— Ten private Bills were this day committed together— Letcher of Kentucky in the Chair— There was one, a claim of a man named King for a vessel alleged to have been impressed into the public Service in the late War and lost—upon which a debate of nearly two hours arose, and it was postponed till next Friday— There were two or three other Bills for giving revolutionary Pensions into which by amendments an allowance of interest for fifty years was introduced. I finally made an objection, in one case, but without success, but there was barely a quorum to vote— The Bills were reported with the amendments to the house— The seven bills reported without Amendment were then passed to be engrossed— Everett then moved to adjourn; but was persuaded by those who wished to pass the amendments, to withdraw his Motion— I immediately renewed it, and said I hoped the house would not without further consideration adopt that principle of the allowance of interest; and the house did adjourn. I rode home— We had company to dine as in the margin— I had invited several others who made excuses— Mr Burges of Rhode-Island finally declined this morning on account of infirm health— W. Lee came an hour before dinner; and read to me partly then and partly in the Evening a Letter which he has been writing to C C. Colden upon the Tariff and its revision. The Ladies did not dine with us at Table—John’s wife being still confined to her chamber.
5. V:15. Sunday.

With Mrs Adams, in the morning I heard Mr Smith from Mark 6:12. “And they went out and preached that men should repent”— A discourse upon the indispensable necessity of repentance. After Church I received a visit from Mr M’Tavish from Baltimore—who was charged with the thanks of Mr Charles Carroll of Carrollton, for my Eulogy and Oration which I sent him last Summer.— Mr Carroll is in his 95th. year—in good bodily health, but his Memory is entirely gone. Mr M’Tavish told me that he himself read my two pamphlets to him twice, and Mrs M’Tavish read them to him also twice, but he remembered nothing of them.— With Mrs Adams I went to see her brother at Mr Johnson’s at his residence in the City to which he removed from the Summer residence, which he had occupied at Weston, beyond Georgetown— The Children were with us for a ride, and Louisa for the visit— After dinner I attended Church alone— Mr Smith’s text was from Psalm 32:11. [“]Be glad in the Lord, and rejoice ye righteous: and shout for joy all ye that are upright in heart.” Different as the character of this text was from that of the Morning, the doctrine drawn from it was the same; the indispensable necessity and duties of Religion. Mr and Mrs Lee were there— Mrs Lee had been this Morning to the Capitol, and heard Mr Durbin, the Chaplain of the Senate— She was much pleased with his performance, and recommended to me to go and hear him. Mr Lee gave me certain apocryphal news respecting Mr Van Buren— I had an Evening visit from Judge Thompson of the Supreme Court— I resumed this Evening the composition of fragments for the draught of a Report from the Committee of Manufactures— My original plan has been disconcerted by the occurrence of intermediate events— I have been diverted from it by other subjects of deliberation upon which my attention has been wasted to no purpose— I have now concluded to take up the subjects by fragments, devoting two or three days to each of them, and then endeavouring to link them together into one system— I glanced this Evening at a new point of Constitutional power—Art 1. Section 8. Common defence.
6. V:15. Monday

Finished the version of the 74th. and began of the 75th. Psalm— Walked to the Capitol and attended at the Committee-room of the Committee of Manufactures at precisely ten O’Clock this Morning. The members came in some time after— Mr B. B. Howell a person interested in the manufacture of Iron attended— Dr Condict—Mr Horn, Mr Worthington, and Mr J. S. Barbour attended— Dayan and Findlay were absent— Mr Howell gave us some information upon the subject of Iron, the duties upon which he appeared to think were in great danger of being reduced— We had a memorial from the Journeymen Tailors of Philadelphia, in behalf of themselves, and of the Tailoresses in that City, against the heavy duties upon manufactured Woollens— The Committee adjourned to Thursday Morning— In the House, it was the day for the presentation of Petitions— The house was deserted by members, flocking to hear the conclusion of Mr Clay’s Speech— Mr Everett’s Resolution with Mr Claytons amendment were postponed— There was some idle-talk about Cherokee and Creek Indians— Mr Hubbard, Chairman of the Committee on Revolutionary Pensions moved that a Bill supplementary to an Act for relief of the Officers of the Revolutionary Army should be taken from the Committee of the whole on the State of the Union and made the special order of the day for next Wednesday— Polk called for a division of the Question— The Committee of the whole on the State of the Union were discharged from the Consideration of the Bill— Polk asked Hubbard to name next Monday for the special order of the day instead of Wednesday to which Hubbard agreed. It was apparent that nothing could be done in the House, and they adjourned about half past two— Mrs Adams dined with her brother and came home late this Evening— Senate passed the Stone Cutter’s Resolution.
7. IV.45. Tuesday.

Finished the version of the 75th. Psalm; and thus one half the task of a complete version of that Book is accomplished— Walk to and from the House— At the House upon E. Everett’s Resolution, Fitzgerald of Tennessee made a speech against the Resolution, and Ellsworth one in its favour. The Silk Bill from the Committee on Agriculture had been made the special order for this day; but was postponed to Thursday— Apportionment Bill— Watmough’s Speech in favour of 44000. Taken by yeas and nays after a Call of the House 102 to 88 for adhering to 48000. C. C. Clay moves 47000. rejected— Irwin of Ohio moves the previous question— Not sustained— Kerr of Maryland moves 44500—Already taken—modified to 44400. Clayton moves an Amendment to give a member for every fraction over 30.000— Adjourned without taking the question. Mr Blair of South-Carolina had been several days absent from the house from Indisposition.— He came in this day upon a call of the House, after the vote was taken; and asked to record his vote, but it was refused— Mr Josiah S. Johnston called me out, and introduced to me a young painter named Chapman who asked me to sit for my Portrait; to be painted for a Gentleman in Louisiana— I promised to call at his room, at ten O’Clock to-morrow-morning— W. Lee was here this Evening, and I returned to him his manuscript Letter— Brawl yesterday between Duff Green and S. B. Barrell, who took to Green an insulting Message from James W. Webb.
8. IV:30. Wednesday.

Mr Brown called upon me this Morning, and said that Mr Lawrence an importing merchant from Boston, was here, and as well as himself was ready to give any information either individually to me, or to the Committee on Manufactures which we might be desirous of obtaining, and which they could afford— I understood him that their particular motive was to shew the evils, which would be hazarded by abandoning the system of progressive minimum duties, or by changing the valuation from the invoice prices, to the value of the Article here, at the place of Sale.— I told him I should be happy to see and confer with him and with Mr Lawrence upon these Subjects, particularly as I thought some of the members of the Committee inclined to the opinion that the change of the place of valuation, and the graduated minimums, would be beneficial. He appeared to be strongly apprehensive of ill effects from these measures but had not time to explain to me how they could operate injuriously.— I told Mr Brown there had been gross misrepresentations in the public newspapers of opinions expressed by me respecting the revision of the Tariff.— That he might be assured I should neither abandon nor sacrifice, the interests of the manufacturers nor of the Constituents whom I represented—though I had said, and still thought that this was an occasion upon which there ought to be a Spirit of mutual concession exercised on both sides.— He said he had believed and understood this to be my opinion, and had so written in a Letter to one of his friends which had been published— I went at half past ten to Mr Chapman’s Room, and sat for my portrait. He has a small exhibition of pictures chiefly copies from Italian Masters. At the House Mr M’Duffie, Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, presented his Tariff Bill, which was in substance a project for reducing all imposts to a duty of 12 1/2 per cent ad valorem upon all importations— There was a long report with the Bill— Mr Ingersoll, a member of the Committee said that he dissented entirely from the Bill, and from the Report of the majority, and with one other member from Pennsylvania, should present a Counter report— Mr Verplanck said that he differed both from the majority and minority of the Committee and should present his views either in a Report of his own, or upon the floor. There was some discussion upon the proposal to print 5000 copies of the Report, but that lays over a day for consideration. Mr Mercer from the Committee on Internal improvement moved the printing of a late Report to the British House of Commons upon the use of Steam-carriages on common roads— This lead to a discussion till Mr Polk called for the Orders of the day— Several bills were read the third time and passed— A Bill or two from the Senate were read the first and second Time and committed— The apportionment Bill was then taken up— The question upon Mr Kerr’s motion to strike out 48000 and insert 44400 as the ratio was about to be taken by yeas and nays—and as it appeared to be the last opportunity for pressing the smaller number I again addressed the house in a very confused and ill-digested Speech presenting however some considerations which had not before, and recurring particularly to the Journal of the Convention of 1787 to shew the principles upon which the Representation had been established in the Constitution. As usual I omitted half what I had intended to say, and blundered in what I did say— I was answered at some length by Coulter of Pennsylvania—Clay of Alabama and Polk of Tennessee; and sustained by Wayne of Georgia, and Letcher of Kentucky who tried with success the good effect of joking. The question was taken by yeas and nays, and
resulted in a tie—97 and 97—the Speaker decided in favour of the change and for the second time we carried our vote— But we could not get the Bill engrossed. Taylor moved to recommit the Bill, with Instructions to strike out 44400. and insert 53000, and took the yeas and nays his motion was rejected 63 to 126. M’Duffie moved that the Bill should be engrossed, but Mitchell of South-Carolina moved to adjourn and it was carried— So, we shall lose it again to-morrow— Rode home in the rain— I received notice that the joint Committee on the Centennial Celebration, would meet at ten to-morrow Morning— Evening industriously occupied— I began this morning the version of the 76th. Psalm.
9. V:15. Thursday.

Finished the version of the 76th. and began that of the 77th. Psalm— Attended the joint Committee of the two houses on the proposed centennial celebration of Washington’s birth-day. They met in the Committee room of the Military Committee of the Senate— There were 22 members of the Committee of the House present— Burges of Rhode Island, and Duncan of Illinois were absent— The Committee of the Senate consisted of Messrs. Clay, Webster, Chambers, Poindexter and Bibb— It was agreed that the Committees should act and vote separately— Mr Clay was Chairman of the Committee of the Senate—and Mr Thomas of Louisiana who offered the Resolution Chairman of the Committee of the House. There was much diversity of opinion and much trifling debate— M’Coy of Virginia and Thompson of Georgia were for reporting that it would not be expedient to hold any celebration of the day— Thompson made that motion, and as it was opposed, rather stiffly urged it, till I observed that it was a difference of opinion upon an important principle, on which I hoped the question would be fairly taken, upon which Thompson withdrew his motion. Mr Clay said there were two modes of celebrating the day, which might be proposed—one by the delivery of a Sermon—the other far less probable by that of an Oration— A motion was then made that Chief Justice Marshall should be requested to deliver an Oration upon that occasion, and after some discussion it was adopted— The Chairmen of the two Committees were appointed a Sub-Committee to make the application and to report his answer to an adjourned Meeting of the joint committee to-morrow Morning— There was some idle debate on the question whether in the event of the Chief-Justices declining the Sub-committee should be authorized to make application to any other person— Mr Bell of Tennessee said there was but one other person to whom with any sort of propriety application could be made if the Chief Justice should decline, and he was a member of the House itself— Without direct notice of this allusion which was to me I said it would perhaps be best not to anticipate, that the Chief Justice would decline— I hoped he would not. If he should, I inclined to the belief that it would be best to make of it a religious ceremony and to have a Sermon— The Meeting then adjourned till to-morrow. In the House, there was a second long debate upon the motion of Mr Mercer at the instance of the Committee on Internal Improvement to print a report to the British House of Commons made in October last, upon the use of Steam-carriages on common Roads— The yeas and nays were taken 120 to 61. Mr Root offered a Resolution to print 5000 copies of it; but the motion got entangled in a question of order and failed— The Apportionment-Bill was taken up— And motion upon motion
was made to strike out the number of 44400 agreed upon yesterday, and the yeas and nays were taken six or seven times— Mr Evans of Maine moved to strike out 44400 and insert 44300 which would give Maine an additional member— Ashley of Missouri moved 42300— Clay of Alabama 47300— A call of the house was demanded, and they prevailed upon Clayton of Georgia to move a reconsideration of the vote of yesterday—and then the house adjourned— I wrote all the Evening
10. IV:30. Friday.

I called at Mr Chapman’s Room, and told him I must postpone my sitting to him till next Tuesday Morning— Attended the centennial celebration Committee—Chief Justice Marshall declines delivering an Oration; alledging his occupation and his infirmities. The Letter from the Sub-Committee to him and his answer were read by Mr Clay— The question what was next to be done ensued— Coll. Drayton offered a Resolution that it would be inexpedient to have an Oration— Mr Bell of Tennessee—Mr Howard of Maryland, and Dr Condict of New-Jersey intimated the wish that another application should be made— They did not name me, but were understood as referring to me— Dr Condict had asked me privately whether I would undertake it, and I had noticed to him the objections in the way— Those objections or others were felt by a large majority of the Committee; and Colonel Drayton’s motion was adopted with my vote and approbation— I was glad to be relieved from the necessity of undertaking this task, for the performance of which the time was too short— It was then determined that the report should recommend that the two Houses of Congress should adjourn over from the 21st. to the 23d. of February; and that the Chaplains should be requested to perform divine Service on that day— Also that the Members of Congress would unite with their fellow-Citizens in other festivities—(a Ball.) Then a Resolution was proposed to take this opportunity to carry into effect a Resolution of Congress for transporting the remains of Washington to be deposited under the Capitol, on that day. This was much debated—and opposed by M’Coy of Virginia—Thompson of Georgia, and Hall of North-Carolina— But it passed by a large majority— It was proposed by Wickliffe of Kentucky. The two Chairmen were charged to make the Report to the respective Houses, and the Committees adjourned.— In the House, M’Duffie, Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, reported a Bill to recharter the Bank of the United States with modifications. 5000 copies of the Bill and Report were ordered to be printed—and also of a Counter-report made by Alexander of Virginia, for the minority of the Committee— Everett’s Resolution was taken up and Hogan of New-York made a very animated and severe Speech, in elegant Language;—but extremely pointed upon Everett’s motives in bringing forward this Resolution— Hogan’s voice is bad—almost feminine in its intonations— His person is not prepossessing, but his action is temperate: and not ungraceful— His diction more polished and ornate than that of any other member of the House, Everett himself not excepted. He was listened to with great attention by the House, and Everett winced under the castigation— But he had not time to reply for the hour expired and the House passed to the orders of the day. A private
Bill for the relief of a man named Knight which had been debated all day last Friday was again discussed—supported by Wardwell, Jewett and Taylor of New-York; and opposed by Cambreleng, Jarvis of Maine and Drayton— It passed nevertheless to be engrossed, by a large Majority— Adjourned over to Monday— My Evening was absorbed by visitors— First Joseph M. White of Florida who made some enquiries upon what he thought the variance between the English and Spanish diction of the Florida Treaty— He is much distressed at the new Nominations for Offices in the Territory— Particularly for the substitution of a worthless person in the place of Judge Brackenridge, an excellent magistrate. Mr Brown and Mr Lawrence were here about two hours on the revision of the Tariff and manufacturing Interests— They will attend the Committee to-morrow. My time slips away from me with appalling rapidity.
11. V:30 Saturday.

Finished the version of the 77th. Psalm. Attended at ten this morning the Committee on Manufactures— I met Mr Horn, on my way to the Capitol. He said he would come if he could in about an hour but he did not— At the meeting—Dr Condict, Dayan and J. S. Barbour were present— Worthington, Horn, and Findlay absent— Findlay has been confined several weeks to his chamber, by illness— Barbour complained of qualms and Sickness at the Stomach, and said he had been playing whist with Senator Poindexter till five O’Clock this Morning. He was quite indisposed and finally went away before the Committee adjourned Mr Brown and Mr Lawrence attended, As did also a Mr Wooldridge from Virginia, proprietor of a Colliery, and very solicitous that the duties upon foreign Coal may not be repealed. There was among the numerous petitions to that effect one from Virginia which amused us much. I read as much of the papers referred to the Committee since their last Meeting as was proper, and various Letters upon the subject of manufactures received by me. There was an Affidavit made by Mr Lawrence and another person left with the Committee— There was a petition from a Rail-road company in the State of Mississippi for a remission of duties upon the Iron to be imported by them for their work. It was agreed that a separate report should be made on this and upon the petitions concerning the repeal of the duties on Coal— I am to draught the Report for the next meeting of the Committee— On my way home, I called upon the Secretary of the Treasury and had a long conversation with him on the Tariff and Bank questions— I asked him when he expected to report, upon the Resolutions of the house calling on him for his plan. He thought not for several weeks— I observed with regard to the last Conversation between us, that I found there was a determined opposition among the manufacturers to the change of the place of valuation, and to the abandonment of the graduated scale of the minimums— He said that in his Report in answer to the enquiries of the Committee on that subject he should give estimates, but no opinions— We had company to dine—the names in the margin above, and much conversation— I took too great a share in it— The art of entertaining is to stimulate conversation, and to take in it very little part.
12. VI.45. Sunday.

My dear wife’s birth-day. 57. I began the version of the 78th. Psalm— A long, and very beautiful Poem—of which I versified this morning the first eight verses; in a most unsatisfactory manner— Last evening I came under the censure of self-reproof, for indiscreet garrulity with my company— This morning I am discontented with the employment of my time in Solitude; and so life passes away—never satisfied with myself— For this there is no remedy— The cause is deficiency of intellect— The means—resistance against the allotment of Providence— The result perpetual disappointment, and the failure of attempts beyond my powers— This has been the character of my existence—Boundless Aspirations—unremitting exertions—Perpetual failures— Nothing can be more desperate than this attempt at a new versification of the Psalms; and yet I pray that I may not give it up in despair— I heard Mr Smith this morning from 1. Timothy 2.8 [“]I will therefore that men pray every where, lifting up holy hands without wrath and doubting:”—and in the afternoon from Romans 1.22. “Professing themselves to be wise, they became fools.” I paid not sufficient attention to these discourses to derive any benefit from them— My thoughts were wandering as too often they do— If I could faithfully devote every hour of the Sabbath to God, I might more profitably occupy every hour of the week to the benefit of mankind— I find a passage in reading the Bible, which I had never particularly noticed before— Part of the last words of David. “But the Sons of Belial shall be all of them as thorns thrust away, because they cannot be taken with hands. But the man that shall touch them must be fenced with iron and the staff of a Spear; and they shall be utterly burnt with fire in the same place”— 2. Samuel 23.6–7— How are the preceding verses of this Chapter to be understood? Who are the sons of Belial? compare the other passages of Scripture where they are named, See Miltons Paradise lost— Is there an inversion of tenses in this passage— The past, the present and the future are often indiscriminately blended in the language of Scripture— What is the import of this figure of Speech—comparing the sons of Belial to thorns, and indicating how they are to be treated— Why are these last Words of David made to precede the Catalogue of his Mighty Men— His numbering of the People— The disorders of his last days— His transfer of the crown and his dying charge to Solomon? Here is a good subject for a historical and moral discourse.
13. VI. Monday.

Dr. Seth Capron an Officer of the Revolutionary War brought me a Letter of Introduction from Mr Burges, member of the House of Representatives from Rhode-Island— He is here as the Agent of a Class of Officers of the Revolution, who he says have been neglected in the Pension Laws. Those who were engaged for three years. They have a Memorial before Congress to which he invited my attention, and for the passage of which he desired the exertion of my influence— I told him they should have all the assistance in my powers I called this morning on the Secretary of the Treasury to make enquiries concerning certain returns of Tonnage for the year 1829. in the Commercial Document of the last
Session of Congress. I thought there must be some error in the Statement of Tonnage which exhibited five hundred thousand Tons less than that returned for the immediately preceding year 1828— Mr M’Lane saw that there must be some error in the document, and said he would have it forthwith examined, and make known to me the result— We could not trace it by the comparison of the two documents of the successive years. At the House I presented the Petition of Jeremiah Draper to be released from Bonds due to the United States, which without reading was referred to the Judiciary Committee—and the Petition of Daniel Merrill for himself and the third Massachusetts regiment during the Revolutionary War— At his request I called for the reading of the Petition and desired it should be printed and referred to the Committee on Revolutionary Pensions— Mr Thomas of Louisiana, Chairman of the Committee for the House of the joint Committee on the Centennial Celebration, made the joint Report of Arrangements and presented two Resolutions for carrying into effect the Resolution of Congress of 19. December 1799. to transfer the remains of George Washington to be entombed under the Capitol— These Resolutions were debated till half past five O Clock and then adopted by yeas and nays 109 to 76— They were also debated and passed by yeas and nays in the Senate 21. to 15— It was past six before I got home to dinner— J. Connell was here in the Evening— He is going to Philadelphia about the last of the week; and I asked him to take charge of a Commission, to confer with Matthew Carey, and his Son, of the house of Carey and Lee concerning a manuscript.
14. V:45. Tuesday

I sat this Morning about an hour to Mr Chapman— In the House General Adair moved a Resolution that the President of the United States, and the members of the Administration should be invited to attend the ceremony of removing the remains of George Washington for interment under the Capitol— The Judges of the Supreme Court, Charles Carroll of Carrollton, the last surviving signer of the Declaration of Independence, James Madison a former President of the United States, and the relatives of the Washington family were added to the invitation— Mr Cambreleng moved to add to the list the name of the late President of the United States; but at my request withdrew the motion— James Bates of Maine moved a Resolution, that the relatives of Martha Washington—G. W. P. Custis should be requested to permit that the remains of Martha Washington should be removed and deposited under the Capitol with those of her husband— This Resolution was adopted, and concurred in by the Senate— They postponed Adair’s Resolution— The Apportionment Bill was then taken up— Mr Clayton withdrew his motion for a reconsideration of the motion by which 44400 had been adopted as the ratio— Evans of Maine’s motion was then carried to reduce the ratio to 44300 was then carried by yeas and nays: after which Polk the Chairman of the Committee which had reported the Bill, moved a recommitment of the Bill with Instructions to strike out 44300 and insert 47700. the effect of this was to give an additional member to each of the three States of Georgia Kentucky and New-York, and it bought the votes of a sufficient number of the Delegations of those States to carry the majority— It had been settled out of doors like every thing else upon this Bill— It prevailed by yeas and nays 104 to 91.
15. IV:30. Wednesday.

I passed an entirely Sleepless Night. The iniquity of this Apportionment Bill, and the disreputable means by which so partial and unjust a distribution of the Representation have been effected agitated me so that I could not close my eyes— I was all night meditating in search of some device if it were possible to avert the heavy blow from the State of Massachusetts and from New-England— I drew up this Morning a short paper, to shew to the members of the Pennsylvania delegation appealing to their Justice and generosity as umpires upon this question— Walking up to the Capitol I met Mr Webster and spoke to him upon the Subject— He said he would make a dead set against the Bill in the Senate. I gave my paper to Mr M’Kennon of Pennsylvania, the member who voted for us, when we carried the ratio of 44000 and the next Morning moved for a reconsideration— I asked him to shew the paper to the other members of the Pennsylvania delegation; and he did to some of them— I spoke to Crawford who said he was willing to take our number; and to Sutherland who said he would if the Senate would send back the Bill with 46000 for the ratio. In the House the Bill was taken up, and Polk from the Committee reported not only the number of 47700 as instructed, but all the remnant of the Bill with the number of Representative, for each State, which was not within the charge of the Committee— When the report was received an amendment was moved to substitute 45500 for 47700. M’Duffie moved the previous question, upon the plea of saving time, and useless debate, but he could not carry it— Then Polk made it a point of order; that the House having instructed the Committee to report a number, no motion of amendment by another number could be received— The Speaker decided that it could. M’Duffie pronouncing the decision perfectly absurd. Polk insisted, persisted, and appealed from the decision of the Speaker, who read from the Manual a Rule which I thought fully sustained him— M’Duffie pronounced it inapplicable, but Polk withdrew his appeal. many numbers down to 42000 and up to 59000 were moved and rejected; and lastly the number reported by the Committee 47700 was adopted and the Bill ordered to be engrossed for a third reading— I hung my harp upon the willow— The Senate passed in amended form the second Resolution sent them yesterday by the House. They struck out all invitations, and made of the Resolution a request to the President of the United States to superintend the removal, and deposit under the Capitol of Washington’s remains— The House concurred in the Amendment.
16. VI. Thursday.

I sat half an hour this morning to Chapman for my Portrait— He is painting it, for a Mr Linton of New-Orleans— A friend of the Louisiana Senator Josiah S. Johnston’s— He told me that he intended to make a picture of the removal of Washington’s remains, and thought it would be an excellent subject; in which I agreed with him— But his purpose will be disappointed— At the opening of the sitting of the House, the Speaker announced the Correspondence between the Vice-President with himself, and John A. Washington the present proprietor of Mount Vernon, and George W. P. Custis the grandson of Mrs Martha Washington— John A. Washington declines giving permission that the
remains of George Washington should be removed from Mount Vernon; though Mr Custis does consent that those of Mrs Martha Washington should be removed. They must remain where they are— This affair is therefore now settled— The Bill for the allowance of the claims of South-Carolina was now taken up— Mr Whittlesey moved to strike out the first and second Sections, which provided for the payment of interest. His reason was that there is now before the House a general Bill, from the Senate for the Settlement of claims for Interest of all the States having such claims arising from the late War— This amendment was not carried— I said a few words in favour of it, in answer to Mr Burges— I was fully prepared to reply to the joint assault upon me, made by him and Edward Everett where the Bill was last before the house. But I saw that all parties had agreed to pass the Bill— That further opposition to it would be vain— That in the House it would be a waste of Time— That out of the House, no interest would be taken in the subject— I therefore suppressed my feelings and my Speech— Whittlesey called for the yeas and nays, and the Bill passed to a third reading with, I think only 46 votes against it— The house was thin, and weary; but about four O’Clock, M’Duffie Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means prevailed upon them to go into Committee of the whole James M Wayne in the Chair, upon four appropriation Bills— They were reported to the house without amendment and ordered to be engrossed— Mr Connell introduced to me this Morning, without the bar of the House a young Englishman named Richardson— And afterwards Mr Doddridge introduced Mr Fawkner a Member of the Legislature of Virginia—now here on a visit, with whom I had some Conversation— Invited them both to dine with me next Saturday— I also sent round an invitation to the Members of the Massachusetts Delegation in both Houses to meet to-morrow Morning, at ten, in the Committee-Room, of the Committee on Manufactures of the House of Representatives.
17. VI. Friday.

Attended a Meeting of the Members of the Delegation from Massachusetts in both Houses of Congress; at ten this Morning in the Committee Room, of the Committee of Manufactures of the House— The two Senators were present; and all the members of the House excepting General Dearborn— Mr Everett retired soon after the Meeting was opened— I had called the Meeting, and stated that my object was that we should consult together to ascertain if we could not devise some means of obtaining some modification of this apportionment Bill— I read to them the paper that I had drawn up and submitted through Mr M’Kennon to the Members of the Pennsylvania Delegation— The Bill is now before the Senate— Mr Webster said he would move its reference to a Select Committee, and there endeavour to obtain a proposal of amendment to reduce the ratio of apportionment to 44000.— It was agreed that the members of the delegation in the House, should converse with those from Pennsylvania, and expostulate with them, upon this outrageous injustice to Massachusetts and to all New-England. I also invited the attention of the Meeting to the attitude assumed by Pennsylvania in the Union for the last four or five years. She has taken the lead of the general Policy of the Country from Virginia, and she is exercising its certainty, for her
own advantage— It might deserve enquiry, whether for that of the whole Union. She had settled the election both of President and Vice-President to her own Satisfaction— She was now doing the same again— The Tariff was her Tariff— The Bank was her Bank— They are now before us for further enquiry, and it might be well to consider the subjects with reference to the interests of the whole as well as to the special interests of Pennsylvania— She had heretofore valued herself upon being an unambitious State; and the complaint to her had perhaps too strongly been against Virginia, of leading or misleading the Union— Virginia has now become a State of subservient policy; and is internally so much convulsed, as to be deserving rather of compassion than of envy— Pennsylvania has now become the domineering State; and her exercise of her supremacy is not encouraging. I read also an extract of a Letter I received two days since from Governor Lincoln stating the interest taken there in the apportionment Bill, and the mortification experienced at the reversal of the decision for a ratio of 44000.— In the House this was one of the days devoted to private Bills; but none of them was taken up— D. J. Pearce moved a recommitment of one of M’Duffie’s appropriation Bills, to strike out an appropriation of 70000 dollars for the Navy-yard at New-York, to insert it for Newport Rhode-Island— Mr Pearce made a Speech of perhaps two hours in support of his motion, which was opposed by M’Duffie, Hoffman, Campbell, P. White, and Cambreleng, and supported by Burges; but was lost by a large majority— There was a Resolution reported by the Committee on the Public Buildings, to have a full-length Portrait of Washington copied from Stewart, by Vanderlyn; to be placed in the Representatives Hall; discussed and adopted— Mr Connell was here this Evening: going to-morrow Morning for Philadelphia— He took my manuscript and directions.
18. V. Saturday—

Attended the Committee on Manufactures— Dr. Condict, John S. Barbour, Dayan and Worthington were present— Findlay and Horn absent— Mr Howell was there, and made earnest representations against the repeal of the duties upon Coal— I had some discussion with him upon the point— There were several petitions and Memorials referred to the Committee two of which were read. Others were left unread, and there seemed to be an indisposition to hear them— Some of the Petitions scarcely deserved a reading. The Committee adjourned to ten O’Clock Tuesday Morning— I gave my reasons for having omitted to draw up a Report against the repeal of the duties upon Coal, apprehending that it would draw on a premature debate upon the whole Tariff. It was however agreed that I should report against the petition from Natchez for a remission of duties upon Iron for a Railway— But after I went into the house, Franklin E Plummer the member from Mississippi, came to me and wished the Committee to hear him in behalf of the Petition— He promised to attend the Meeting of the Committee next Tuesday— In the House a Resolution reported by the Committee on the Public-Buildings for causing a full length marble Statue of Washington, to be made by H. Greenough, and placed in the Rotundo, was discussed and adopted by yeas
and nays—124 to 50.— The Bill for the Relief of Susan Decatur and others was at length called up, and debated in Committee of the whole till 4 O’Clock. Phineas L. Tracy moved as an Amendment that the distribution of the Sum 100000 dollars should be made according to the rules of the Prize Act— This was debated nearly two hours, but the Amendment was rejected— Then D. J. Pearce moved an amendment by which the three Sisters M’Knight should receive 10,000 dollars of the money, and Mrs Decatur only 21000— This was opposed by M’Duffie, Cambreleng, Everett, and especially by J L. Kerr— Pearce was supported by Sutherland— I was violently tempted to speak in behalf of the M’Knights; but I suppressed my feelings and my propensities— I must speak very seldom if I am to speak with any effect— Mrs Klapp, whom I gave away last April, has recently lost her husband and Sutherland says is left almost destitute, with his three children— Cambreleng read a Letter from Mary M’Knight to Mrs Decatur declaring she had authorised no application to be made in her behalf for any portion of the grant— The Committee rose after four, and are to sit again— We had company to dine— Mr Faulkner brought an apology from Mr Doddridge, who had visitors arrived from Virginia this Morning, by whom he was detained.
19. V. Sunday

Heard Mr Gurley in the place of Mr Smith, in the morning from James 1.22. [“]But be ye doers of the word, and not hearers only; deceiving your own selves.” and in the afternoon from Romans 12.16. “Be of the same mind one toward another. Mind not high things, but condescend to men of low estate. Be not wise in your own conceits.” Mr Gurley, is a preacher of very different character from Mr Smith— Plain, practical and persuasive; he has neither metaphysical refinement, nor oratorical flourish in his discourses— Mr Smith abounds in both— Mr Gurley has a very handsome person and florid countenance,—and a very good voice, not very well modulated— This is an art of which few of our public Speakers have even a conception. Preachers less than any others— Mr. Gurley’s doctrine like his texts was pious, humane and benevolent, totally free from all sectarianism, and such as any preacher of any Christian denomination might have delivered— In the interval between the Services I received a visit from Mr Joel R. Poinsett, who came to take leave, being on the point of departure to return to Charleston South-Carolina— He went last Summer to Europe, and spent some months in England, where he thinks a total Revolution of Government is in full and rapid progress—an opinion in which I concur— My Journal runs again unavoidably in arrear Stanbury the Reporter for the Intelligencer was not in the House, when I made the Speech upon the apportionment Bill on the 8th. instt. Notes more imperfect than the Speech itself were taken by their other Reporter, and Seaton gave them to me two days ago requesting me to revise them— From them I am writing off the whole Speech; a task not without labour, and which absorbs all the time I have at home— Stansbury reports very correctly, but if he is not there, the reports are so defective that a Speaker who has any regard for his own reputation or for the effect of his Speeches upon the public mind, must write them off, either before or after delivering them— This Consideration with many others should admonish me against all loquaciousness in the house. Let the Lesson not be lost.
20. V. Monday.

Finished the version of the 78th. Psalm— One of the longest and most difficult in the whole collection— But what is difficulty? Whether I ought to pray for life and health to complete this task, or for grace and self-knowledge to abandon it, and commit to the flames what I have done, I do not know— There is a level of poetical power which a man may attain, and which he cannot transcend— It differs in different men; and mine is very low— I have known it these fifty years, for so long have I written verses, and yet I persevere— I have published very little, and the success of that little has been in no wise flattering— My prose writings published have fared not much better— Why should I longer weary the world with verse or prose?— This was a heavily rainy, gloomy day— I rode to the Capitol— Being Monday, the States were successively called for presentation of Petitions, a most tedious operation in practice though to a reflecting mind a very striking exemplification of the magnificent grandeur of this Nation, and of the sublime principles upon which our Government is founded— The forms and proceedings of the House—this calling over of States for Petitions—the Colossal emblem of the Union over the Speaker’s chair—the Historic Muse at the Clock the echoing pillars of the Hall, the tripping Mercuries who bear the Resolutions and Amendments between the Members and the Chair—the calls of ayes and noes with the different intonations of the answers from the different voices—the gobbling manner of the Clerk in reading over the names— The tone of the Speaker in announcing the vote, and the varied shades of pleasure and pain in the countenances of the members on hearing it would form a fine subject for a descriptive poem— There was little done in the House after receiving the Petitions. There was a bill for the relief of insolvent debtors partly discussed and postponed— A Question upon printing papers relating to Railways and Canals in which Mercer and Ellsworth took part. But the house was thin—the day was dark—and Carson before three moved to adjourn; because it was so melancholy— They accordingly adjourned, to the great indignation of Hubbard of New-Hampshire, who has the Claimants for Revolutionary Pensions in charge and burns with zeal to assist them— He asked for the yeas and nays on the adjournment, and to fool him into fury they were refused— He went out of the House almost sputtering with rage— I went out to walk home; but found it pouring with rain and return’d by the western door, and poked into the Senate in chamber— They were in Session, but very soon adjourned. I met there Governor James Barbour, who is returning from Baltimore. His family have been there from the time of the Clay Convention of which he was President. He left them there and has now been to fetch them back— He said he should proceed homeward the first fair day— He told me that Mr Madison’s health was very bad; and that for some time it was feared he would not survive the winter. But that he was now better. I spoke with Mr Ruggles Chairman of the Senate’s Committee on Claims, about the Bill for the relief of Jotham Lincoln— He said Mr Silsbee had the papers, but that the Committee had decided another case founded on the same principle, against the claimant. I had received an invitation from E. F. Chambers and others Committee of a party for a public dinner at Barnard’s on the centennial day, to attend the dinner as a guest— J. S. Johnston told me that they wanted me not only to attend; but to make Toasts for them and a Speech— I said, my health would not permit me to attend, and that I was a bad Toast maker as he knew— I might have added I was a worse Speech-maker. Mr.
Clay spoke to me; and asked when the Committee on Manufactures would report— I said not for several weeks— He asked if we should not notice M’Duffie’s Anti Tariff Report and Gallatin’s Memorial— I said we should probably meet some of their arguments— He said he had been so much occupied that he had not found time to read them— I told him that M’Duffie’s Report was one of his dinner-Speeches without its fury— I had read only a small part of Mr Gallatin’s Memorial— I said my attention had quite unexpectedly to myself, but necessarily been diverted from the Tariff to this iniquitous apportionment Bill: he said it was a very unjust one, and they would endeavour to change the ratio in the Senate, but they had got a very bad Committee— I said something to him of my plan for representation of the whole people and he referred me to a mode of giving a Representation to fractions in the Constitution of Kentucky— Genl. Samuel Smith accosted me and immediately began upon his new controversy with Mr Clay— He appeared to be deeply wounded. Clay treated him with such extreme severity that Smith who has four score years upon his head is as my father used to say upon the compassionate list— All parties think Clay pressed him too hard— Smith told me almost with tears in his eyes, that he had come with a deliberate resolution by all possible means to avoid all controversy whatever with Mr Clay, and he intimated a wish that I would give him a written confirmation of his Statement of what passed between him and me, relating to the British Statute concerning the Colonial Trade— I told him I would give him such a Statement if he desired it—but I saw no necessity of it for him; was inasmuch, as Mr Clay had not denied the correctness of that part of his Statement— There was no issue between them upon that point— Smith said my father had once appealed to him for a Statement, which he had very cheerfully given him— The Truth is that in dissuading him from his demand of a certificate from me I mean it in kindness—for if I do give it, the truth will bearer harder upon him than anything that has been said of him by Mr Clay. I went in to the Library, and took out the Volume of Constitutions of the United States— On going again to the Eastern door of the Capitol I found my Carriage had been there; and Kirk being told I was gone, had gone away— I walked home in the midst of a cold heavy rain; following great part of the way a Company of Militia from Philadelphia, marching through the flood with a fine band of music— They had come from Philadelphia to join in the projected centennial procession. I wrote this evening till I was falling asleep over my paper.
21— V:30. Tuesday— Snow—hard frost, Fahrenheit 20.

Change through Snow in the Night to sharp frost this morning. Began the version of the 79th Psalm—very bad— Attended the Committee on Manufactures— Dr Condict, Dayan and Worthington were there— Findlay (who has a fit of the gout) J. S. Barbour and Horn absent— Mr Plummer of Mississippi came and endeavoured to prevail upon the Committee to report in favour of the remission of the duties on the iron wanted for the Natchez Railway company— They referred him however to the Act of May 1830: and we agreed to postpone the report against the remission till he can write to the Memorialists and receive their answer— I read to the Committee a Letter to me from W. E. Richmond of Providence containing much valuable information respecting the state of the manufactures in Rhode-Island— I read likewise a Letter from Zechariah Eddy of Middleborough— The Committee adjourned to Saturday Morning— In the House, business was not much better than yesterday— House very thin— Mr Wirt was arguing a
a cause before the U.S. Supreme Court for certain Missionaries to the Indians imprisoned by the State of Georgia— This is a Cause of deep interest; and there were fifty or sixty Members of the House who left their Seats to hear him— Everett’s resolution was called up. He modified it again—proposing to refer it to the Committee on Public Lands; with power to send for persons and papers; and to report such measures as they should deem expedient in the premises— Everett had discovered that he could do nothing with his enquiry while it was in his own hands— Wickliffe is Chairman of the Committee of Public Lands— He has been a fiery red Jackson man, but is coming over to Clay— He published yesterday a Correspondence about an attempt of his in January 1830 to prevail upon Genl. Jackson to hold Cabinet Councils— Wickliffe convoked a Caucus of five Kentuckians, and three Tennesseans to effect this— Eaton, and the Globe Newspaper have represented this as a Caucus of Calhounites to get Eaton turn’d out from his Office of Secretary of War.— Wickliffe publishes Certificates and Letters from the five Kentuckians utterly denying this—but the three Tennesseans White, Grundy and Polk decline answering— The Globe declines publishing the Correspondence, and Wickliffe publishes it in the National Intelligencer— This new movement of Everett’s unhinged entirely the household Troops in the house— Bell of Tennessee moved the reference to the Committee on Indian Affairs of which he is himself Chairman. Drayton moved to refer it to the Committee on the Judiciary. Wilde of Georgia moved to postpone the question for a fortnight— Wickliffe rose to discuss the question, and the Speaker pronounced it not debateable— Wickliffe appealed from the decision; and the Speaker, evidently wrong, after a moment of reflection gave up the point— Davis of S. Carolina Chairman of the Committee on the Judiciary, said that disguise this matter as we might it was a charge of fraud upon a public Officer of the Government with which the Committee on the Judiciary had nothing to do, and he hoped it would not be referred to them, but to the Committee on Public Lands— J. W. Taylor twice moved the previous Question and the second time succeeded— The postponement for two weeks was rejected, and the reference to the Committee on Public Lands carried by yeas and nays 92. to 76. An extreme relief to Everett, and a severe annoyance to the Tennessean—as well as a high gratification to Wickliffe; affording him a good vehicle for his Transit— I gave Gales my Speech of the 8th on the Apportionment Bill with a request that he would publish it, as soon as possible, and furnish me 100 copies of it extra—which he promised me— I asked Mr Webster who came in to the Lobby of the House, to read my Speech before the debate upon the Bill should come on in the Senate— He said he would— The Committee of the Senate have reported the Bill without Amendment— Mr Blair of S.C. gave Mr Webster and me, a Letter from a Mr Witherspoon to read— It proposes in the Event of Congress’s doing nothing satisfactory to them about the Tariff to secede from the Union— They make a great distinction between this and Nullification. I told Blair I had heard the Nullifiers would oppose them in the project of seceding— He said he supposed they would— They did not want to have the Tariff repealed.— The House adjourned soon after two O’Clock over till Wednesday— There is a tart Correspondence between Senator Poindexter from Mississippi and Hoffman of New-York, approximating to a duel, in the newspapers of this day. W. R. Davis of S.C. is Poindexter’s friend.— Also a Correspondence with Angel and Soule—New-York Members—
22. VI. Wednesday. Centennial Birth-day of Washington

The Solemnities intended for this day at this place lost all their interest for me by the refusal of John A. Washington to permit the remains of George Washington to be transferred to be entombed under the Capitol. A refusal to which I believe he was not competent, and into the real operative motives to which I wish not to enquire— I did wish that this Resolution might have been carried into execution— But this wish was connected with an imagination, that this federative Union was to last for ages. I now disbelieve its duration for twenty years, and doubt its continuance for five— It is falling into the fear and yellow leaf— For this among other reasons I determined that my celebration of this day, should only be by sharing in its devotions— I attended the performance of divine Service at the capitol where a very ordinary prayer was made by Mr Post the Chaplain to the House of Representatives and a singular though not ineloquent Sermon was delivered by Mr Durbin, Chaplain to the Senate— His text was from Revelations 4.11. “Thou art worthy O Lord, to receive glory and honour and power: for thou hast created all things, and for thy pleasure they are, and were created.”— The discourse was not written; nor was it composed to be preserved— It was extemporaneous and yet well suited to the occasion— It exalted the character of Washington perhaps too much— There were close approaches to the expression of a belief, that there was something supernatural in his existence. There seemed little wanting to bring out a theory that he was a second Saviour of mankind— That he had a charmed Life, and was protected by a special Providence was explicitly avowed as a belief— The religious character of Washington was dwelt on with great emphasis. The House was well filled, but not crowded— The 148th. and 100th. Psalms were sung, without instrumental Music, and a hymn at the close— The Vice-President, and Speaker of the House of Representatives were there, and the Judges of the Supreme Court; but neither the President of the United States nor any member of his Cabinet. Miss Silsbee sat next to me. I walked home with John Sergeant— William S. Smith was here— There was a dinner party at Barnard’s Hotel—about 100 National Republicans at which Mr Webster presided— An Evening Ball at Carusi’s Saloon; and a Ball at Georgetown— To all these I received invitations, and declined them all, on account of my Catarrhal Cough which is again troublesome— I spent the Eve at home, writing. There was a strange Correspondence published in this day’s Globe between Governor Poindexter Moore of Alabama and Miller of South-Carolina, John T. Bergen a Representative from New-York, and James Watson Webb— I finished this Morning the version of the 79th. Psalm—
23. V. Thursday.

Began the version of the 80th. Psalm, to my own grievous dissatisfaction. I had received yesterday a Petition to the Postmaster General, from the principal inhabitants of Quincy, asking for a daily Mail between that place and Boston, with a Mail from Boston through Quincy to New-Bedford— I called with it this morning at the General Post Office; and left it for the Postmaster-General who was not there— At the House, Drayton had offered a Resolution for altering the Rule of the House which devotes Friday’s and Saturday’s to the consideration of private business, so that Saturday
alone should be thus specially appropriated— Various amendments were proposed, and after a discussion of two hours or more they were all rejected, as well as the motion itself. There ought to be no private business before Congress— There is a great defect in our Institutions by the want of a Court of Exchequer or chamber of Accounts. It is judicial business, and Legislative Assemblies ought to have nothing to do with it— One-half of the Time of Congress is consumed by it; and there is no common rule of Justice for any two of the cases decided. A deliberative assembly is the worst of all tribunals for the Administration of Justice— Mr. Clayton of Georgia smuggled in by consent of the House a Motion for the appointment of a select Committee to examine into the Affairs of the Bank of the United States with power to send for persons and papers— It must lay over a day for consideration— The Orders of the day were postponed and the General Appropriation was taken up in Committee of the whole J. W. Taylor in the Chair— I fully intended not to have opened my lips on this bill, and my purpose is as seldom as possible to enter into any debate. But the impulse to take part is continually recurring and I cannot always resist it. I rose this day twice—once to support a contested item of appropriation for surveying of the public Lands—and once to object to an amendment proposed by Archer, Chairman of the Committee of Foreign Relations. The appropriation which I supported was adopted. The amendment proposed by Archer was to add 35000 dollars for contingencies to an item of 2500 dollars for a dragoman at Constantinople— I asked what it was for? Archer declined giving the information, but said that the Committee, composed of members entertaining different political opinions were unanimous in recommending the Amendment— I still objected, though declaring my confidence in the Committee— My opposition would probably have been of no avail, but M’Duffie joined in it, and in his peremptory tone said the information must and should be given—if the Committee chose it might be given to the House, but given it must be— The amendment was then rejected without counting. Some other amendments were adopted and the Bill was reported to the House.— Adjourned near five— I wrote till Midnight, unable still to bring up my arrears of Journal.
24. VI:45 Friday.— Fahrenheit 12.

Another change in the Night to severe Cold— I lose in the Morning what I borrow upon the Night— The Sun was up this morning when I rose— I called again at the General Post-Office, and saw this Morning the Postmaster General. He told me that he had already given the order asked for by the Petition from Quincy, for a Mail from Boston through Quincy to New-Bedford, and thus a daily Mail between Boston and Quincy— I called at Chapmans room; but he had been to Alexandria and was not returned; on going back towards Gadsbys, I met him; but his room was not in order, and I promised to call some other Morning— I then called at Gadsby’s and saw Mr Silsbee— Asked him for the papers in the case of Jotham Lincoln Admr— The Bill at three successive Sessions has passed the House of Representatives, but always stopped in the Senate. Silsbee afterwards sent me the papers— Silsbee told me of the Battle between Genl. Walter Jones and Thornton the second Comptroller at the Supper table of the Ball at Carusi’s Saloon on Wednesday. Jones broke two decanters upon Thornton’s head— The dinner at Barnard’s was very delightful, and Mr Webster made one of his most eloquent Speeches. The President
and Vice-President were both invited and both declined attending the dinner. My Letter and Toast were read, and well received— The President took no part in any of the celebrations of the day— In the House the Resolutions on the Table were taken up, and disposed of in order— I moved a Resolution to call for the Papers relating to the Negotiation with Turkey; partly on account of the item of appropriation proposed yesterday by the Committee on Foreign Relations, and the Chairman’s affectation of Secresy— But my motion could not be received without the unanimous consent of the House; and General Root objected that he had been a month waiting for an opportunity to offer a Resolution, and had not been able to offer it yet. Everett advised me to move for a suspension of the rule—but I preferred acquiescing in Roots objection— Branch had offered a Resolution for papers relating to the Live-Oak Plantation— A controversy between him and White of Florida R. M. Johnson moved that the House would hold next Monday an Evening Session at 7. O’Clock to take up the Post-Office and Post-road Bill— And after much discussion and various motions to change the day, and to meet at eleven A.M. which all failed Mr Johnson’s Motion was carried— The Resolution offered some weeks ago by Le Compte for a Committee to require into and report upon the expediency of an Amendment to the Constitution to make the Judges of the Courts of the United States hold their Offices for a Term of years, was called up and the House refused to consider it by yeas and nays 124 to 46. The Bill for the relief of Stephen Decatur came up, in Committee of the whole Jesse Speight Chairman. D. J. Pearce produced Letters from Mrs Decatur and Mary M’Knight and a Statement by Mrs Twiggs, somewhat discreditable to Mrs Decatur, charging her among other things of having given to Mr Stratford Canning a gold snuff-box which had belonged to her husband. Carson insisted that the Statement was a forgery, and charged it as infamous and disgraceful— But Twiggs is a Georgian— Wayne and Wilde testified to his character and Carson retracted and apologised for his censure— The debate became exceedingly ardent and somewhat bitter. About four the Committee rose, and the House adjourned— In the Evening Mr J. S. Hastings of Boston spent about two hours with me— He is interested in the Glass Manufactory, and said that Statements from the New-York Convention, concerning that interest would soon be presented here— But he appeared much more prepared for a modification of the Tariff conciliatory to the South, than any other manufacturer that we have seen— He told me that a great majority of the People of the Eastern Section of the Union were convinced that it would be indispensably necessary.
25. VI— Saturday. Snow—

Late rising yesterday morning; and a visitor last Night prevented my writing at home almost entirely. But I finished my version of the 80th. and began that of the 81st. Psalm— And at the house I began yesterday in the midst of business a Letter to Mr Webster upon the Apportionment Bill— A desperate case of atrocious injustice, against which I persevere without hope. I finished the Letter in the House this day. The Committee on Manufactures met at ten this Morning— Dr Condict, Barbour, Dayan and Worthington were present. Horn and Findlay absent. B. B. Howell and James Lynch were there— They took the
affidavits of Samuel Lawrence, and ofEdmonds, to carry to the Secretary of the Treasury, and asked for the Statements of J. B. Brown, and P. H. Schenk which I could not find— We read two Memorials, and adjourned to meet again next Wednesday Morning at half past ten— In the House Mr Branch’s Resolution was taken up— Mr White of Florida moved an amendment which brought on an extremely violent debate between them, full of the most offensive personalities— Charges of direct falsehood cast to and fro— Branch accusing White of speculating to pocket some hundreds of dollars upon the Government and upon his Constituents and White retorting that Branch had wasted 45000 dollars of public money, upon useless agencies in this business, and of having appointed last Winter one of his near relatives on this Service, and increased his Salary 600 dollars after his own dismission from Office— This was continued by speech and counterspeech for nearly two hours— Carson was beginning to speak on the side of Branch when the Speaker stopped him, and said he had indulged Mr Branch, on account of the peculiar situation he was in with reference to the executive Office he had recently held, and in which his conduct had been made a topic of animadversion—but that this indulgence could be extended no further— Branch finally acceded to White’s Amendment with a modification suggested by Wickliffe, and the Resolution was adopted— I renewed my request for the consent of the House to offer a Resolution, this Morning, and Root now suffered it to be received, though he objected to the next one that was offered— Mine lies over till Monday— The Bill for the relief of Susan Decatur was taken up again in Committee of the whole— Edward Everett produced a Letter from Mrs. Decatur explaining the donations which in Mrs Twiggs’s Letters she was charged with having made—and Everett produced the gold snuff-box itself which she was said to have given to Mr Canning—and the box was paraded about the house and deposited on the Clerk’s Table. It was like the bloody robe of Caesar produced by Mark Antony in the Forum, and with much the same motive— Here it was practically to give the lie to Mrs Twiggs— But Pearce still sustained her, by corroborative statements and particularly by intimating that the Snuff-box had been offered to Mr Canning, though not accepted by him— Upon which Everett said Pearce was too tough for him—and I said I had no doubt the statement was true— For I did not believe Mrs Twiggs capable of a wilful falsehood. M’Duffie too sung out a premature Io Triumphe upon the production of the box— Pearce’s Amendment was however rejected by a vote of 70 to 80. at least so announced by the Speaker.— Watmough made an eloquent Speech in Mrs Decatur’s favour, as White of Louisiana had done yesterday— Blair of South Carolina moved to strike out the first Section of the Bill.— This introduced the debate upon its Merits— M’Duffie wanted to press it into the House, and prevailed upon Blair to withdraw his motion; but it was immediately renewed by Dickson of New-York— The Committee rose after four, and the House immediately adjourned. Walking homeward Mr Wilkin, member from Orange County New-York lent me his Umbrella— We had company to dine as named in Margin— John Holmes Senator from Maine had promised he would come but failed— The Company in general were less known to us than usual, and the party was accordingly less pleasant— Mr Plummer, Member of the House from Mississippi, is a native of Pittsfield Massachusetts— He is a member of the Committee on the Public Lands and said they had this Morning in that Committee a debate as sharp, as that afterwards in the House between Branch and White. Clay of Alabama had moved to ask to be discharged; but was outvoted 4 to 3.
26. V:30. Sunday—

Snow melting off— On going to the Presbyterian Church, I found scarcely any one there; and a doubt whether the morning Service would be performed— I returned to St. John’s Church and heard a Stranger from Alexandria— He read prayers for Sexagesima Sunday—and preached from John 5.40—“And ye will not come to me that ye might have life.” There is a rule of Grammar which seems to be infringed by this Sentence. Conjunctions couple like cases; like Moods and Tenses— I think it should be that ye may have life—or it should be ye would not come to me— The conjunction that couples will and may—or it couples would and might. will and might make a match ill sorted—a mariage forcé— The Doctrine of the Sermon was moderate Calvinism— Total depravity of the Will, and earnest exhortation to repentance. In the afternoon I heard Mr Smith from Luke 15.32. [“]It was meet that we should make merry and be glad: for this thy brother was dead, and is alive again; and was lost, and is found.”— The doctrine drawn by Mr Smith from his text was Religion is Life— And in this respect there was a remarkable coincidence between the morning and afternoon texts though the Sermons were by different preachers and of different denominations— Mr Smith made no use of the narrative in the Story of the Prodigal Son, only mentioning it as a beautiful Parable— Mr Smith always connects the conclusion of his discourse immediately with his text; and then fills up the canvass with argument, illustration and declamation— I spent the Evening at home, retrieving my arrears.
27. V. Monday.

Finished the version of the 81st. Psalm. Attended the House, at Noon— Petitions called for by States— My Resolution, with an additional call for copies of the Negotiations with Turkey from the year 1819. was adopted without Opposition— Archer—Chairman of the Committee of Foreign Relations declared he had no objection to it—and Root came to me and apologised for having objected to the reception of my Motion last Friday— He said if he had known it was political, he would not have objected— Mr Clayton’s Motion for a Select Committee to investigate the Affairs of the Bank of the United States, was called up, and there was some question whether it should be considered— Upon this the yeas and nays were not taken, though called— Clayton was suffered to proceed, and read from a paper, fifteen charges or he said Articles of Indictment, which he said could be proved against the direction of the Bank and upon which he commented rather feebly.
