M’Duffie answered him instanter— Taking his paper— Reading his charges successively, and refuting them one by one, perhaps too much at length; but completely: shewing that they were either ordinary, lawful, and useful operations of the Bank; or frauds of a gross and sordid kind, of which there was no evidence even sufficient to lay the foundation for a justifiable suspicion— Mr Patton of Virginia rose, but being reminded by the Speaker that it was within five minutes of four O’Clock; moved an adjournment which immediately took place— Judge Baldwin sent and called me out from my seat to say that he wished to have some conversation with me upon the Tariff, as we had once had upon the Missouri Question— I told him the only leisure time I had was in the
evening, and he promised to call upon me to-morrow evening at six O’Clock. I saw Mr John Taliaferro also outside of the Bar and in the house— There was a recess from four O’Clock till seven. Mrs Adams with John and his wife went this Evening to a Concert of Musicians from Germany— Just as we were going out after dinner Dr Wallace of Warrenton Virginia, called to visit us—just from home—seemingly very fine health, though he told us that he still drug’d himself with rattlesnake’s poison— He rattled in his Conversation as much as ever, and promised to breakfast with us to-morrow— Mrs Adams with John and his wife went to a Concert of German Musicians at Carusi’s Saloon, at the door of which I left them and attended the Meeting of the House from 7 to 11. in the Evening— In Committee of the whole upon the Post Office Bill— E. Root in the Chair. The Bill was gone through State by State, and followed by the Territories— The Chairman of the Post-Office Committee had a copy of Bill, in which he said there were a number of Amendments agreed to by the Committee, and which he wished the Committee of the whole to adopt all together, and without reading— J. Davis, called for the reading of these but before they were half read through a motion was made to suspend the reading—on taking the Question there was no Quorum— Committee rose and reported no Quorum— Call of the House moved and commenced— Soon after suspended and the House adjourned— It was Midnight when I got home— J. S. Barbour shewed me an additional Section, which he told me he meant to propose— That Postmasters whose emoluments amounted to more than 300 dollars a year should be appointed upon nomination of the President, by and with the advice and consent of the Senate— Mr Carson of North-Carolina told me that the Speaker Stevenson had informed him that they were determined to run for Van-Buren as Vice-President—even in North Carolina; and that he had answered him—if you carry him it shall be over my dead body.
28. VI. Tuesday.

Made the version of the 82d. Psalm— Dr Wallace breakfasted with us— After Breakfast Mr Nicklin came in—An Anti Tariff, free-trade man—Who discussed the question with me warmly— At half past 11. I left Dr Wallace at the General Post-Office— He had never before seen Mr Nicklin, but undertook to give his character by his physiognomy— At the House Mr Doddridge made a Report from the Committee on the District of Columbia—Against a delegate—Against a local legislature—against recession. I sent my Letter on the apportionment Bill to Mr Webster— My Speech of the 8th was reported in the Intelligencer of this Morning. My plan for a representation of the whole People is too late—and if it were not I have no influence to carry it through. This is one of the many political disappointments of my Life— Mr Clayton’s Motion for a select Committee to investigate the affairs of the Bank of the United States was taken up, and discussed by Patton, Polk and Cambreleng for the Resolution, and Jenifer, Branch, and Huntington against it— Adjourned at 4. O’Clock, half a dozen Members starting up to speak.— Judge Baldwin was here this Evening and unfolded to me his plan for the settlement of the Tariff question— It is simple enough—20 per Cent upon all importations of Articles whether with or without foreign competition— Then gradually shortened credits, finally to be turned into Cash payments—and a considerable duty upon Sales at Auction. This is his Panacea— He has revealed it to General Hayne and to Mr
M’Duffie, who did not tell him that they or the South would be satisfied with it, but Hayne told him that he wished one of the members from Pennsylvania would bring it forward. He has also conferred upon the subject, with the President and with the Secretary of the Treasury, Mr M’Lane— The President is entirely in favour of his plan, and will support it. The Secretary of the Treasury had objections to it, but upon explanations given they were so far removed that he will also probably support the plan— But if he should not, the President will.— Judge Baldwin said he had told the President that he considered his plan of so much importance that he would go to any quarter for support to it—even to Mr Clay— The judge assured me, that he would always be ready to give me any information that I might desire— I have considerable doubts of the efficacy of his plan, or whether it will prove acceptable—but it will deserve grave consideration.
29. VI. Wednesday.

Began the version of the 83d. Psalm— One of extreme difficulty being full of proper names, which will not accommodate themselves to measure and numbers— An old revolutionary Officer named Bird, now residing in the State of New-York, but a native of Massachusetts called to ask my aid to a claim for a pension which he has before Congress— A Bill in his favour has passed the House of Representatives at two preceding Sessions, and at the last was reported without amendment by a Committee of the Senate, but not acted on, for want of time— Bates Cook is his Representative with whom he requested me to consult, and to whom I did speak of the claim— At the Committee on Manufactures, Dr. Condict Worthington and Dayan were present— Absent Findlay (confined with the gout) Horn, and J. S. Barbour— Mr J. S. Wright of the Canton Woollen factory and Mr Hazard of Rhode-Island were before the Committee and made several Statements respecting wool from Smyrna, Adrianople, Constantinople, and Buenos-Ayres, and the manufactures from them of Satinets and Kerseys— In the House, the Post-Office-Bill was taken up, in the Committee; reported to the House, and passed to be engrossed. Mr Vance offered a Section to make Post Masters whose emoluments exceed 300 dollars a year appointable by nomination of the President, by and with advice and consent of the Senate. Rejected in Committee of the whole 76 to 54— He said he would offer it, upon another Bill— The other orders of the day were all postponed, and the Revolutionary Pensioner Bill taken up— An Amendment was moved by Standifer and resisted by Pendleton— Hubbard Chairman of the Committee and Ward of New-York made long Speeches in favour of the Bill— Adjourned at four O’Clock— Mr J. S. Hastings spent an hour of this Evening here— Conversing upon glass manufactures; the lead of Missouri—Ashes and Coal. He said he was with the President this Morning, who in the presence of several persons styled the Senate a faction— He also declared his disposition to adjust the Tariff question by Cash payments, Auction Sale duties and 20 per Cent ad valorem duties— Hastings himself is for a very essential modification of the Tariff— Mrs Tudor sent me a Message requesting to see me, and I promised to call upon her to-morrow Morning— I wrote a Letter to Governor Lincoln

Day— I rise later in the morning than I had in the preceeding months. Now between 5 and 6. Read three Chapters of the Bible. Versify two Stanzas of the Psalms— Breakfast at nine— Walk to the Capitol. Committee on Manufactures twice a Week— House from Noon till four. Home to dine— Evening writing in my chamber till 11. or 12.
